item.title: Automata
item.description: Q1: T/F, if F explain why. Q4: regular expression, 5 separate q Q2/Q3: DFAs and NFAs Product construction: ∩ ∪ of DFAs Subset construction: NFA to DFA Quotient construction: State minimization Set theory Complement in Σ∗: L=Σ∗−L associative: (A∪B)∪C(A∩B)∩C(AB)C​=A∪(B∪C),=A∩(B∩C),=A(BC).​ commutative: A∪BA∩B​=B∪A=B∩A​ null set null set ∅ is the identity for ∪ and annihilator for set concatenation A∪∅=A and A∅=∅A=∅ set {ϵ} is an identity for set concatenation {ϵ}A=A{ϵ}=A Set union and intersection are distributive over set concatenation A∪(B∩C) A∩(B∪C)​=(A∪B)∩(A∪C)=(A∩B)∪(A∩C)​ Set concatenation distributes over union A(B∪C) (A∪B)C​=AB∪AC=AC∪BC​ DFA DFA#definition Let δ:Q×Σ→Q, thus δ^:Q×Σ∗→Q δ(q,c)→p therefore δ^(q,w)→p regularity Important δ^(q,ϵ) δ^(q,xa)​=q=δ(δ^(q,x),a)​ Important a subset A⊂Σ∗ is regular if and only if there exists a DFA M such that L(M)=L Important All finite languages are regular, but not all regular languages are finite examples Show L is regular where L={x∣x%3=0∪x=ϵ}, with Σ={0,1} Three states, q0​,q1​,q2​, where q0​ denotes the string mod 3 is 0, q1​ denotes the string mod 3 is 1, and q2​ denotes the string mod 3 is 2.

item.description: Somewhat impromptu supper club hosted by yours truly.

item.title: Atmospheric properties for exoplanets
item.description: Ref: slides features. H=ωmH​gkB​T​ solid or dash solid q larger mean molecular weights? B: shallow features ⇒ higher mean molecular weights mass-metallicity trend Question Can we detect clouds in exoplanets? Clouds suppress atmospheric chemical signatures Important Introduced a degeneracy between cloud-top pressure and mean molecular weight clouds/winds on giant planets.

item.title: philosophy
item.description: Toute idée fausse finit dans le sang, mais il s'agit toujours du sang des autres. C'est ce qui explique que certains de nos philosophes se sentent à l'aise pour dire n'importe quoi.

item.title: steady-state error
item.description: See also slides Important System type is the number of integrators in the forward path, thus value of n .

item.title: Alignment
item.description: See also: Overton Window and this blog on alignment research The act of aligning oneself with a particular group or ideology. This can be done for a variety of reasons, including: To gain social acceptance To gain power To gain resources Often known as a solution to solve “hallucination” in large models token-generation.

item.title: Overton Window
item.description: also known as window of discourse A window into the ideas that frames ideas that people are prepared to entertain. All ideas outside the window are not seriously considered.

item.title: ethics
item.description: Closely connected to value theory, or moral philosophy. Kantian ethics presupposes that there is a universal moral law that applies to all rational beings, or his deontological ethics framework that based on “categorical imperative”.

item.title: Root mean square
item.description: See also: pdf problème 1. The Root Mean Square (RMS) value of a signal f(t) that is periodic with period T is given by the equation T1​∫0T​(f(t))2dt​ It can be shown that the RMS value of u(t)=Bsinωt is 2​B​ 1.a Square wave The square wave function is defined as: f(t)={10​if 0≤t<2T​if 2T​≤t<T​ import sympy as sp t = sp.symbols('t') T = 2 RMS = sp.sqrt(1/T * sp.integrate(1, (t, 0, T/2))) RMS = 2​1​ 1.b Sawtooth wave A sawtooth wave function is defined as: f(t)=T2A​(t−2T​) import sympy as sp t = sp.symbols('t') T = 1 A = 0.5 f_t = 2 * A / T * (t - T/2) RMS = sp.sqrt(1/T * sp.integrate(f_t**2, (t, 0, T))) RMS = 63​​ 1.c sine wave A general form of the sine wave can be written as f(t)=Asin(ωt+ϕ) Amplitude is 2.3, no phase shift RMS = 2​2.3​ problème 2.

item.title: Second-order systems
item.description: problem 1. Consider the following system: Question Using the properties of second-order systems, determine Kp​ and Kd​ such that the overshoot is 10 percent and the settling time is 1 second.

item.title: Camus
item.description: Of the absurd reasoning and existentialism. The Myth of Sisyphus Absurd and suicide Suicide is the solution for the absurd: People never died because of ontological arguments Suicide is often the result of people who didn’t find worth in the living Life is not worth living therefore I took the easy way out as a paradox: Suicide is the justification of meaning of life ← the most important question for philosophers From Nietzchean prose, those who say “no” acts as if they said “yes”: Schopenhauer Fantasise the act of eluding: Hope of another life one must “deserve” or trickery those who lives not for life itself but for some great idea that will transcend it, refine it, give it meaning, and betray it.

item.title: Voltage-controlled electromechanical systems
item.description: See lab notes and prelab. Question Do you notice a pattern in the DC gain values you calculated? If so, what is that pattern? All DC gain are constant around A≈98.76, and Input voltage wrt DC gain is linear.

item.title: Graphs
item.description: See also slides Node as information and edges as relationship between data Directed acyclic graph (DAG) Application: Merkle DAG undirected. (\mathcal{N}, \mathcal{E}) N: set of vertices E: set of undirected edges: E⊆N×N path is a sequence of nodes and edges connect two nodes.

item.title: Min heap and binary search tree
item.description: Problème 1. Consider the following sequence of values S=[3,42,39,86,49,89,99,20,88,51,64] Note We can represent tree textually via the following representation 13 ( 11 ( 8 ( 2 4 ) 12 ( * 1 ) ) 7 ( 5 6 ( 99 * ) ) ) Where we use ∗ as a placeholder for a missing child for those nodes that only have a single child.

item.title: Giles Deleuze
item.description: French philosopher, known for his work on the concept of multiplicity, being and affirmation. Also work on critical philosophy and the study of sense and value.
